title: Jazz singer Al Jarreau dead at 76 just days after announcing retirement from Grammy-winning career due to exhaustion
text:
Opinion JAZZ LEGEND DIES Jazz singer Al Jarreau dead at 76 just days after announcing retirement from Grammy-winning career due to exhaustion 
The singer, whose career spanned 50 years and saw him win seven Grammy Awards, died surrounded by his family BY YASMIN JEFFERY GRAMMY-winning jazz singer Al Jarreau has died in Los Angeles at the age of 76. 
The shock news comes just days after the singing star announced his retirement from touring. Reuters 3 Jazz star Al Jarreau has died aged 76 mere days after announcing his retirement from touring 
The cause of death was not immediately clear, though the star was in hospital for exhaustion when he died. 
The singer, who transcended genres over his 50-year career in the music industry, was surrounded by his wife, son and other close family members when he passed away . 
Jarreau was hospitalised earlier in the week and was said to have been improving slowly. 
The Milwaukee-born star won seven Grammy Awards throughout his career. Reuters The star won seven Grammy Awards over the course of his 50-year career in the music industry 
His biggest single was 1981’s “We’re in This Love Together” from the album Breakin’ Away. 
Jarreau also performed vocals on the 1985 song “We Are the World”, and sang the theme to TV’s Moonlighting. 
He is one of a handful of musicians to have won Grammy Awards in three separate categories — jazz, pop and R&B. 
Time Magazine once described the star as the “greatest jazz singer alive”. Speaking in 2014 with The Arizona Republic , Jarreau relished in his crossover tendencies. 
He said: “I grew up in Milwaukee, and I took it all in. I want it all. 
“Don’t cut me off at the pass and say I can’t listen to Muddy Waters because I’m a jazzer. It is with the deepest of sadness to inform you Al Jarreau passed away this morning, at about 600am LA time. He… https://t.co/P3pPccO3vk 
— Al Jarreau (@AlJarreau) February 12, 2017 
“Or I can’t listen to Garth Brooks because I’m a jazzer. Get out of here,” he joked. 
Jarreau was also an athlete who earned a master’s in vocal rehabilitation. 
He first worked as a counsellor in San Francisco, playing jazz in his spare time. 
He didn’t record his first album until he was 35. EPA 3 Jarreau, who was once described as the ‘greatest jazz singer alive’, leaves his wife and son behind 
A statement on the star’s website read: “His second priority in life was music. There was no third. 
“His first priority, far ahead of the other, was healing or comforting anyone in need.” 
Jarreau leaves his wife Susan and son Ryan behind. 
A donation page for fans has been set up for the Wisconsin Foundation for School Music.
